alt_statements.statement: Tech companies have every right to make money, but if they’re using my data to do it, they owe me straight answers and real choices. I don’t want 50 pages of legal mumbo-jumbo—I want to know exactly what they’re collecting, how they’re selling it, and a simple way to say “no” without losing basic access. They should be held liable if they’re careless with people’s information, just like any other business that mishandles customer property. My data is mine first, their product second.

As someone who’s pretty active online and cares a lot about ethics and sustainability, I think tech companies should treat user data like something they’re borrowing, not owning. They should clearly explain what they’re collecting, get real consent, and give us easy options to opt out of tracking or selling our info. If they profit from our data, there should be strict rules to prevent abuse, discrimination, or manipulation—especially of vulnerable people—and strong legal consequences when companies break those rules.

As someone who grew up long before the internet and now sees how much of our lives are tracked, I believe tech companies have a moral duty to treat user data with the same respect and care they’d give to something sacred. They should be completely transparent about what they collect and how they profit from it, get clear consent instead of burying everything in fine print, and never sell or share data in ways that could harm people or manipulate them. With the power they hold, they’re responsible not just to shareholders but to the common good, especially to vulnerable groups like the elderly and the poor.

As someone who’s spent a career caring for people, I think tech companies should treat our personal data with the same duty of care—using it only with clear consent, strong privacy protections, and honest explanations in plain language.
